I am using ant to run my unit test something like: 

 <junit fork="yes" showoutput="true"  printsummary="yes"
   failureproperty="unitTest.failed" dir="${path.unitTestSrc}" >
    <formatter type="xml"/>
         <batchtest todir="${test.report.dir}" >
            <fileset dir="${path.classes}">
                <include name="${includeTestCasePattern}"/>
            </fileset>
         </batchtest>
  </junit>

When I use the batchtest and forking it seems to be loading and
running each *TestCase.class in it's own JVM.  I figured this out
because I setup some a caching object and it seems to get wiped out
after every test case class.  I was hoping to not have to go to the
database and load all of the data every time I run each test case.   I
attempted to not fork, however, it's causing all kinds of issues from
not forking.  I gave up on that for the moment and then tried putting
all of my test cases into a suite and just run the suite.  That works,
however, when I do that the html report just has one class and every
method.  I would like to have all test case class run in one JVM and
have the test report spit out a TEST*.xml file per class that is run.
  So my question is what is the easiest solution to this problem?  I'm
not if I should take the time to figure out the problems with the
forking or just write a different XML report formatter or something
completely different.  Thanks.
